Widget Notifications Refresh rate 5 minutes 30 minutes Hourly 4 hours 8 hours Twice a day Daily Grateful notes as a notification Show random grateful notes as a permanent notification Share About Gratus Gratus is a simple app to promote good vibes and positivity. It offers a simple interface to encourage to write about the things we're most grateful for.

The feeling of being grateful is often associated with happiness and good mental health. Quoting Dr. Robert Emmons, professor of Psychology at the University of California "There are many things in our lives, both large and small, that we might be grateful about". Gratus will help you remember about these things and make you smile every time you're reminded of them.

Gratus is dedicated to my sister and my girlfriend, for whom I'm very grateful. You'll still be prompted every refresh %1$s Where are my notes being saved to? All the notes you post on Gratus are saved to your device's local storage, private Gratus data directory. They are inaccessible by normal means since Android protects app's private data with SELinux and strict permissions. %1$s How to backup my notes? Currently Gratus uses Android's built-in backup system that was introduced with Android Marshmallow, so if you wipe your device and start anew you can restore everything back to what it was. In a future update a more transparent backup functionality will be implemented, probably Google Drive. %1$s What is the heart/like counter for? It serves two purposes. One is to encourage you to come back to Gratus and re-read older grateful notes and eventually "like" them again. Second is influencing how often notes appear in the notification/widget. More "likes" equal a higher chance on having those notes show up. Also since you can sort the notes list by "likes" instead of date, when you open the app you will see your favorite notes right on top %1$s Why isn't Gratus translated to my language? Translating apps is costly because of the initial investment (lots of words to begin with) but with every update new strings are added that need to be translated (and it costs more money than the one time in-app purchase to unlock all the features). I make use of crowd sourcing and good will of amazing users that use their own free time to translate these strings for free. Eventually the app will be localized into the most common languages.
